text:
We have come across several heartbreaking tales as #MeToo movement paved its way in India. A lot of people came out and shared their decades-old stories of being harassed and molested. Joining the bandwagon is actor Parvathy, who says it took her years to realize that she was assaulted as a child and that it’s still a daily affair for her to consider herself a survivor.
“It happened to me when I was very young. It took me 17 years to realise it did happen to me. I was three or four years old. I didn’t ask for it. But I was assaulted. And then to speak about it, it took me another 12 years,” Parvathy said at the Jio MAMI 20th Mumbai Film Festival with Star on Tuesday.
She added, “To sit and speak of it as a fact that has happened to me…but not being defined by my gender. So, I sit here as a person first and then rest of the tags come in. But you know where the survival part comes… it’s still a struggle for me on a daily basis to realise it, acknowledge it and get past it. It’s a daily affair. And then let my friends know, my parents, cope with it. It becomes an extreme exercise on a daily basis.”
She further added how she was brought up as a pretty confident and outspoken girl. Still, she wondered did she ask for it or did she deserve it.

“As a personal experience, I know it’s still a daily affair for me to consider myself a survivor. Survival is not just a physical thing. It’s a constant mental affair. So, I kind of really draw a lot of power from that word,” she said.
Parvathy is also the member of the Women in Cinema Collective (WCC), an outfit of women in the Malayalam film industry.
(With agency inputs)
